# Mid-Atlantic Ridge

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b2/Mid-
atlantic_ridge_map.png)](/wiki/File:Mid-atlantic_ridge_map.png)

[](/wiki/File:Mid-atlantic_ridge_map.png "Enlarge")

A map of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge

The **Mid-Atlantic Ridge** (**MAR**) is a [mid-ocean ridge](/wiki/Mid-
ocean_ridge "Mid-ocean ridge"), a [divergent](/wiki/Divergent_boundary
"Divergent boundary") [tectonic plate](/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate
tectonics") or constructive plate boundary located along the floor of the
[Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"), and part of the
[longest mountain range in the world](/wiki/List_of_mountain_ranges#By_length
"List of mountain ranges"). In the North Atlantic it separates the
[Eurasian](/wiki/Eurasian_Plate "Eurasian Plate") and [North American
Plates](/wiki/North_American_Plate "North American Plate"), and in the South
Atlantic it separates the [African](/wiki/African_Plate "African Plate") and
[South American Plates](/wiki/South_American_Plate "South American Plate").
The ridge extends from a junction with the [Gakkel Ridge](/wiki/Gakkel_Ridge
"Gakkel Ridge") (Mid-Arctic Ridge) northeast of [Greenland](/wiki/Greenland
"Greenland") southward to the [Bouvet Triple
Junction](/wiki/Bouvet_Triple_Junction "Bouvet Triple Junction") in the South
Atlantic. Although the Mid-Atlantic Ridge is mostly an underwater feature,
portions of it have enough elevation to extend above sea level. The section of
the ridge that includes [Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland") is known as the
**Reykjanes Ridge**. The ridge has an average spreading rate of about 2.5
centimetres (0.98 in) per year.[1]

## Discovery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mid-
Atlantic_Ridge&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Discovery")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8e/Pangea_animation_03.gif)](/wiki/File:Pangea_animation_03.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Pangea_animation_03.gif "Enlarge")

Pangaea's separation animated

A ridge under the Atlantic Ocean was first inferred by [Matthew Fontaine
Maury](/wiki/Matthew_Fontaine_Maury "Matthew Fontaine Maury") in 1850. The
existence of the ridge was discovered during the [expedition of HMS
_Challenger_](/wiki/Challenger_expedition "Challenger expedition") in 1872.[2]
A team of scientists on board, led by [Charles Wyville
Thomson](/wiki/Charles_Wyville_Thomson "Charles Wyville Thomson"), discovered
a large rise in the middle of the Atlantic while investigating the future
location for a [transatlantic telegraph
cable](/wiki/Transatlantic_telegraph_cable "Transatlantic telegraph
cable").[3] The existence of such a ridge was confirmed by sonar in 1925[4]
and was found to extend around the [Cape of Good Hope](/wiki/Cape_of_Good_Hope
"Cape of Good Hope") into the [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian
Ocean") by the [German Meteor expedition](/wiki/German_Meteor_expedition
"German Meteor expedition").[5]

In the 1950s, mapping of the [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth")'s ocean floors by
[Bruce Heezen](/wiki/Bruce_C._Heezen "Bruce C. Heezen"), [Maurice
Ewing](/wiki/Maurice_Ewing "Maurice Ewing"), [Marie Tharp](/wiki/Marie_Tharp
"Marie Tharp") and others revealed that the Mid-Atlantic Ridge had a strange
[bathymetry](/wiki/Bathymetry "Bathymetry") of valleys and ridges,[6] with its
central valley being [seismologically](/wiki/Seismology "Seismology") active
and the [epicenter](/wiki/Epicenter "Epicenter") of many
[earthquakes](/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake").[7][8] Ewing, Heezen and Tharp
discovered that the ridge is part of a 40,000-km-long essentially continuous
system of [mid-ocean ridges](/wiki/Mid-ocean_ridge "Mid-ocean ridge") on the
floors of all the Earth’s oceans.[9] The discovery of this worldwide ridge
system led to the theory of [seafloor spreading](/wiki/Seafloor_spreading
"Seafloor spreading") and general acceptance of [Wegener](/wiki/Alfred_Wegener
"Alfred Wegener")'s theory of [continental drift](/wiki/Continental_drift
"Continental drift") and expansion in the modified form of [plate
tectonics](/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate tectonics"). The ridge is central to
the breakup of the hypothetical [supercontinent](/wiki/Supercontinent
"Supercontinent") of [Pangaea](/wiki/Pangaea "Pangaea") that began some 180
million years ago.

## Notable features[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mid-
Atlantic_Ridge&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Notable features")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Iceland_Mid-
Atlantic_Ridge_Fig16.gif/150px-Iceland_Mid-
Atlantic_Ridge_Fig16.gif)](/wiki/File:Iceland_Mid-Atlantic_Ridge_Fig16.gif)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Iceland_mid_atlantic_ridge.JPG/205px-
Iceland_mid_atlantic_ridge.JPG)](/wiki/File:Iceland_mid_atlantic_ridge.JPG)

In Iceland the Mid-Atlantic Ridge passes across the
[Þingvellir](/wiki/%C3%9Eingvellir "Þingvellir") National Park, a popular
destination for tourists

The Mid-Atlantic Ridge includes a deep [rift valley](/wiki/Rift_valley "Rift
valley") that runs along the axis of the ridge along nearly its entire length.
This rift marks the actual boundary between adjacent tectonic plates, where
[magma](/wiki/Magma "Magma") from the [mantle](/wiki/Mantle_\(geology\)
"Mantle \(geology\)") reaches the seafloor, erupting as [lava](/wiki/Lava
"Lava") and producing new [crustal](/wiki/Oceanic_crust "Oceanic crust")
material for the plates.

Near the [equator](/wiki/Equator "Equator"), the Mid-Atlantic Ridge is divided
into the North Atlantic Ridge and the South Atlantic Ridge by the [Romanche
Trench](/wiki/Romanche_Trench "Romanche Trench"), a narrow submarine trench
with a maximum depth of 7,758 m (25,453 ft), one of the deepest locations of
the Atlantic Ocean. This trench, however, is not regarded as the boundary
between the North and South American Plates, nor the Eurasian and African
Plates.

## Islands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Islands")]

The islands on or near the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, from north to south, with their
respective highest peaks and location, are:

**Northern Hemisphere (North Atlantic Ridge)** :

  1. [Jan Mayen](/wiki/Jan_Mayen "Jan Mayen") ([Beerenberg](/wiki/Beerenberg "Beerenberg"), 2277 m (at [71°06′N 08°12′W﻿ / ﻿71.100°N 8.200°W﻿ / 71.100; -8.200](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=71_06_N_08_12_W_)), in the [Arctic Ocean](/wiki/Arctic_Ocean "Arctic Ocean")
  2. [Iceland](/wiki/Iceland "Iceland") ([Hvannadalshnúkur](/wiki/Hvannadalshn%C3%BAkur "Hvannadalshnúkur") at [Vatnajökull](/wiki/Vatnaj%C3%B6kull "Vatnajökull"), 2109.6 m (at [64°01′N 16°41′W﻿ / ﻿64.017°N 16.683°W﻿ / 64.017; -16.683](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=64_01_N_16_41_W_)), through which the ridge runs
  3. [Azores](/wiki/Azores "Azores") ([Ponta do Pico](/wiki/Ponta_do_Pico "Ponta do Pico") or Pico Alto, on [Pico Island](/wiki/Pico_Island "Pico Island"), 2351 m, (at [38°28′0″N 28°24′0″W﻿ / ﻿38.46667°N 28.40000°W﻿ / 38.46667; -28.40000](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=38_28_0_N_28_24_0_W_))
  4. [Saint Peter and Paul Rocks](/wiki/Saint_Peter_and_Paul_Rocks "Saint Peter and Paul Rocks") (Southwest Rock, 22.5 m, at [00°55′08″N 29°20′35″W﻿ / ﻿0.91889°N 29.34306°W﻿ / 0.91889; -29.34306](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=00_55_08_N_29_20_35_W_))

**Southern Hemisphere (South Atlantic Ridge)** :

  1. [Ascension Island](/wiki/Ascension_Island "Ascension Island") (The Peak, Green Mountain, 859 m, at [07°59′S 14°25′W﻿ / ﻿7.983°S 14.417°W﻿ / -7.983; -14.417](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=07_59_S_14_25_W_))
  2. [Saint Helena](/wiki/Saint_Helena "Saint Helena") ([Diana's Peak](/wiki/Diana%27s_Peak "Diana's Peak"), 818 m at [15°57′S 5°41′W﻿ / ﻿15.950°S 5.683°W﻿ / -15.950; -5.683](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=15_57_S_5_41_W_))
  3. [Tristan da Cunha](/wiki/Tristan_da_Cunha "Tristan da Cunha") ([Queen Mary's Peak](/wiki/Queen_Mary%27s_Peak "Queen Mary's Peak"), 2062 m, at [37°05′S 12°17′W﻿ / ﻿37.083°S 12.283°W﻿ / -37.083; -12.283](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=37_05_S_12_17_W_))
  4. [Gough Island](/wiki/Gough_Island "Gough Island") ([Edinburgh Peak](/wiki/Gough_Island "Gough Island"), 909 m, at [40°20′S 10°00′W﻿ / ﻿40.333°S 10.000°W﻿ / -40.333; -10.000](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=40_20_S_10_00_W_))
  5. [Bouvet Island](/wiki/Bouvet_Island "Bouvet Island") ([Olavtoppen](/wiki/Olavtoppen "Olavtoppen"), 780 m, at [54°24′S 03°21′E﻿ / ﻿54.400°S 3.350°E﻿ / -54.400; 3.350](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&params=54_24_S_03_21_E_))

## Geology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Mid-Atlantic_Ridge&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Geology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Expl2286_-_Flickr_-
_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg/220px-Expl2286_-_Flickr_-
_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg)](/wiki/File:Expl2286_-_Flickr_-
_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Expl2286_-_Flickr_-_NOAA_Photo_Library.jpg "Enlarge")

Basaltic rocks of the MAR collected by the Hercules ROV during the 2005 [Lost
City](/wiki/Lost_City_Hydrothermal_Field "Lost City Hydrothermal Field")
Expedition.

    _For a general explanation of mid-oceanic ridges, see[mid-oceanic ridge](/wiki/Mid-oceanic_ridge "Mid-oceanic ridge") and [seafloor spreading](/wiki/Seafloor_spreading "Seafloor spreading")_

The ridge sits atop a geologic feature known as the **Mid-Atlantic Rise** ,
which is a progressive bulge that runs the length of the Atlantic Ocean, with
the ridge resting on the highest point of this linear bulge. This bulge is
thought to be caused by upward convective forces in the
[asthenosphere](/wiki/Asthenosphere "Asthenosphere") pushing the [oceanic
crust](/wiki/Oceanic_crust "Oceanic crust") and
[lithosphere](/wiki/Lithosphere "Lithosphere"). This divergent boundary first
formed in the [Triassic](/wiki/Triassic "Triassic") period, when a series of
[three-armed](/wiki/Triple_junction "Triple junction") [grabens](/wiki/Graben
"Graben") coalesced on the supercontinent [Pangaea](/wiki/Pangaea "Pangaea")
to form the ridge. Usually, only two arms of any given three-armed graben
become part of a divergent plate boundary. The failed arms are called
_[aulacogens](/wiki/Aulacogen "Aulacogen")_ , and the aulacogens of the Mid-
Atlantic Ridge eventually became many of the large river valleys seen along
the [Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas") and [Africa](/wiki/Africa "Africa")
(including the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi
River"), [Amazon River](/wiki/Amazon_River "Amazon River") and [Niger
River](/wiki/Niger_River "Niger River")). The [Fundy Basin](/wiki/Fundy_Basin
"Fundy Basin") on the Atlantic coast of North America between [New
Brunswick](/wiki/New_Brunswick "New Brunswick") and [Nova
Scotia](/wiki/Nova_Scotia "Nova Scotia") in [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") is
evidence of the ancestral Mid-Atlantic Ridge.[10][11]

qa.question: iceland sits atop what type of plate boundary

nq_111499_5.Query Analysis: The query asks about the type of tectonic plate boundary that Iceland sits atop.
nq_111499_5.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that Iceland sits atop the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, which is a specific type of plate boundary.
nq_111499_5.Document Content Analysis: The document describes the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, its characteristics, and its location, including its passage through Iceland's Þingvellir National Park. It explains that the ridge marks the boundary between adjacent tectonic plates and involves magma reaching the seafloor, producing new crustal material.
